content:
Finished. Finally. My hand is cramped, my back hurts, and they cut half of it anyway.

Going to bed. Don't talk to me.
historicalContext: Jefferson spent 17 days writing the Declaration of Independence. Congress edited out about 25% including his anti-slavery passage.

content:
Can't stop shaking. Hands won't stay still. It's done. We actually did it.

I should eat something. Did I eat today? I don't remember eating.
historicalContext: The Continental Congress adopted the Declaration of Independence on July 4, 1776.

content:
My gout is flaring up, I'm exhausted, and we may have just signed our own death warrants.

Anyone else need a drink?
historicalContext: Signing the Declaration was treason against the Crown, punishable by death. Franklin was 70 years old and suffered from gout.

content:
The market was half empty today. Everyone's at the State House watching those men argue.

I just need flour. FLOUR. Is that so much to ask.
historicalContext: While Congress debated independence, daily life continued for most Philadelphians.

content:
Franklin changed my words again. 'Self-evident' instead of what I wrote.

It's better. I hate that it's better.
historicalContext: Franklin edited Jefferson's 'sacred and undeniable' to 'self-evident' - one of history's most famous editorial changes.

content:
They're reading something from the steps. Can't hear a word - too many people. Someone's crying. Someone else is cheering.

What is HAPPENING.
historicalContext: The Declaration was first publicly read in Philadelphia on July 8, 1776.

content:
Had it read to the men. They pulled down that statue afterward. Made a mess.

Good for morale though. We need that right now.
historicalContext: Washington had the Declaration read to troops in New York. Soldiers then tore down the statue of King George III - later melted into musket balls.

content:
John's letter finally arrived. My hands were shaking so bad I could barely open it.

The children think I've gone mad. Maybe I have.
historicalContext: News of the Declaration reached Abigail Adams days later by letter. Mail between Philadelphia and Massachusetts was slow.

content:
Today. We voted today. July second. Remember this day.

...why is everyone talking about the fourth? THE SECOND.
historicalContext: The actual vote for independence was July 2, 1776. Adams predicted it would be celebrated - but July 4th became the holiday instead.

content:
More ships. Counted to forty and stopped. What's the point.

Can't let the men see me like this. Keep my face still. Nod. Look confident. Throw up later.
historicalContext: By mid-July, over 400 British ships had gathered - the largest fleet Britain ever assembled.

content:
The colonials think signing a paper changes something. Paper doesn't stop bullets.

Missing my mum's cooking. The food here is terrible.
historicalContext: British forces largely dismissed the Declaration as meaningless. Many soldiers were far from home for the first time.

content:
Johnny asked when papa is coming home again. I said 'soon.'

I've been saying 'soon' for months.
historicalContext: John Quincy Adams was 8 years old. His father would be away for years during the Revolution.

content:
Been working toward this for YEARS. Since before some of these men could shave. And now it's done and I just feel...

Tired. I just feel tired. Is that wrong?
historicalContext: Samuel Adams had been organizing resistance since the 1760s. The moment of independence was anticlimactic for many who'd long fought for it.

content:
My neighbor's celebrating 'independence' with a bonfire. Nearly set the barn on fire.

Some of us have to work tomorrow, William.
historicalContext: Celebrations of independence sometimes got out of hand. Not everyone was equally enthusiastic.

content:
Third letter to Abigail this week. She's going to think I've lost my mind.

Maybe I have. Can't sleep anyway.
historicalContext: John and Abigail Adams exchanged over 1,100 letters. Their correspondence is one of the most complete records of the Revolutionary period.

content:
Walked the lines again tonight. Can't sleep.

The men trust me. That's the worst part. They actually trust me.
historicalContext: Washington often inspected his troops at night when he couldn't sleep. He carried enormous responsibility for poorly trained militia facing professional soldiers.

content:
Everyone keeps congratulating me. Shaking my hand. Patting my back.

I just want to go home and see my wife.
historicalContext: Jefferson's wife Martha was frequently ill. He was deeply devoted to her and anxious about being away.

content:
Someone asked me what I thought about what we'd done. Made a joke. Everybody laughed.

Can't remember what I said. Can't remember what I actually think either. Seventy years old and still deflecting.
historicalContext: Franklin was known for his witty remarks, but privately grappled with the enormity of declaring independence.

content:
The cow got out again. Chased her for an hour. In this heat.

Managing a farm alone with four children is not what I imagined my life would be.
historicalContext: Abigail Adams ran the family farm and raised four children while John was away - a burden shared by many women whose husbands were fighting or serving in Congress.

content:
The mosquitoes here are ungodly. Bites on top of bites. My sergeant says stop complaining.

Easy for him to say from inside his tent.
historicalContext: British soldiers suffered greatly from American insects and climate. Many came from cooler England.

content:
Some of these men are going to talk us out of it. I can feel it. Cowards.

...I understand them though. I'm terrified too.
historicalContext: Debate on independence was fierce. Many delegates feared execution for treason if they failed.

content:
Independence or not, crops still need harvesting. Sun doesn't care about politics.

Back hurts. Everything hurts.
historicalContext: For farmers, summer 1776 was harvest season regardless of political events. The rhythms of agricultural life continued.

content:
Wrote to Martha. Couldn't tell her how scared I am.

Some things you don't put in letters.
historicalContext: Washington and his wife Martha exchanged letters throughout the war, though Washington was careful about what he committed to paper.

content:
Someone asked if I was proud. Proud?

We haven't WON anything yet. We signed a piece of paper. Paper doesn't stop cannons. Ask me again in a year. If we're still alive.
historicalContext: Independence was declared but the war was far from won. British forces vastly outnumbered the Continental Army.
